repository.corpname: University of Washington Libraries Special Collections

did.abstract: Papers of a Filipino-American author, poet, and migrant laborer

bioghist.p: Carlos Sampayan Bulosan (c. 1911– September 11, 1956) was a Filipino American author, poet, and activist. A chronicler of the Filipino American experience in during the 1930s-early 1950s on the West Coast, he is best remembered for his semi-fictionalized autobiographical novel America Is In the Heart (1946). Though Bulosan was only 42-45 years old when he died of tuberculosis-complicated pneumonia in Seattle in 1956, he left behind a large body of poems, novels, short stories, plays, and correspondence on a wide range of interrelated topics. Bulosan’s work described the experience of growing up poor in a rural area of the Philippines, chronicling the conditions of neocolonialism after American occupation and centuries of Spanish colonialism. Bulosan’s work captures the “push” factors that drove himself his generation to the United States. Like Bulosan, they hoped to find a better future and forged resilient and adaptive communities in the face of an often-hostile and exploitative European American culture in the United States. Bulosan is remembered as a progressive anti-colonial, pro-labor, humanitarian voice by an array of communities including Asian/Pacific Islanders, organized labor, academics and intellectuals, and a wide array of social justice; ethnic; and activist communities.

separatedmaterial.p: Photographs related to Carlos Bulosan can be found in the Carlos Bulosan Photograph Collection, PH Collection 1156; it is likely that they were removed from the Carlos Bulosan Papers.

scopecontent.p: Contains writings, annotated manuscripts, correspondence, taped recordings of reminscences and tributes by friends and associates, lists, publications, clippings, financial records, miscellany, ephemera, scrapbook.

Some of the writings and manuscripts are microfilm copies of originals either from this collection or owned by other individuals or repositories. The bulk of the collection is typed, annotated manuscripts, or correspondence.

altformavail.p: Some of the Bulosan papers are also available on microfilm.

acqinfo.p: The bulk of the papers in this accession was collected by the Bulosan Manuscript Committee in 1959.

did.unittitle: Unpublished manuscript by Trinidad A. Rojo

processinfo.p: With the following exceptions, all the material on microfilm is copied from originals in the Bulosan Papers: Microfilm reel no. 3 was copied from a Manila Public Schools textbook, Philippine Prose and Poetry; reel no. 4 material was copied from original manuscripts held by the University of Chicago Library; reel no. 5 was copied from material originally owned by Josephine Patrick. Patrick had also loaned the originals contained on reel no. 6 in September 1977. She then donated the originals in November 1977. The letters addressed to Josephine Patrick (1953-1955, undated) on reel no. 8 were returned to Patrick after filming.

custodhist.p: Originals in possession of Josephine Patrick.

scopecontent.p: Contains sound cassette and CD-ROM copies of recordings of individuals reminiscing about their friendship with Carlos Bulosan. The originals are reel-to-reel sound recordings (1959-1960) in Accession No. 0581-012.

In the Chris Mensalvas interview conducted by Joseph Butterworth on September 19, 1959, Mensalvas stated his belief that Bulosan came to the United States in 1931 and landed in Seattle. He may have stayed in Seattle for a time but then went to Yakima to pick fruit. He wound up in Lompoc, California, where Mensalvas thinks they first met. When Carlos was unemployed, he lived with Mensalvas, as did Aurelio, Carlos's brother. This housing consisted of a two bedroom apartment with a kitchen, shared by four men.
Jo Patrick, Barry Hatten and Red Gibb recall Carlos Bulosan's later years in an interview recorded at Mary Gibson's apartment on June 19, 1960.

phystech.p: Listening equipment necessary for cassette audio tapes or CD-ROM. Contact Special Collections for details.

scopecontent.p: Autographed manuscript poem "The language of flowers" (for Victor Cabebe), with letter to Josephine Patrick on verso (Seattle, 1953 April 14).
